clinical_study.brief_title: Women's Responses to a Mindfulness-Based Body Scan: A Pilot Study
clinical_study.official_title: Women's Responses to a Mindfulness-Based Body Scan: A Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock: PTSD develops after trauma and is marked by intrusive memories, avoidance of reminders, negative changes in mood and cognitive processes, and dysregulated physical and emotional stress reactivity. PTSD disparately affects twice as many women as men (8.0% vs. 4.1%), and finding effective treatments for these women is critical to reduce poor health outcomes associated with PTSD. Mind-body therapies (MBT), using the mind in combination with the body to facilitate healing hold promise to enhance PTSD treatment by improving stress regulation. While MBT reduce PTSD symptoms long-term, women with PTSD may initially experience distress, leading to treatment avoidance. This pilot study will explore women's initial responses to MBT, the prevalence of adverse responses, and which women are at risk for adverse responses in a sample of 60 participants with a history of trauma and varying levels of PTSD symptoms. Study participants will attend one in-person study visit at the Clinical Research Center (CRC) at Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC), where they will complete self-report measures of stress and affect before and after one session of a MBT exercise, and obtain ECG data during the visit. During the CRC visit, data will be collected by a CRC nurse trained to carry out the study protocol. A subset of the sample will complete a semi-structured telephone interview within two weeks following completion of the study visit.

detailed_description.textblock: The proposed single-group study will use a pre-post design to assess participants' responses to one exposure to a mindfulness-based body scan in a sample of women with a history of trauma and varying levels of PTSD symptoms. Quantitative measures will assess self-reported state positive affect, negative affect, and anxiety before and after the body scan; physiologic vagal tone before, during, and after the body scan; and psychosocial characteristics expected to influence responses. Individual semi-structured interviews will be conducted with a subsample of women to learn about their subjective experiences related to the body scan.

primary_outcome.description: Positive affect will be measured with The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule-Short Form (PANAS-SF), a 20-item questionnaire with 10 items assessing positive affect and 10 items assessing negative affect. Participants will be asked to "indicate to what extent you feel this way right now, that is, at the present moment" on a five-point scale; 1 = very slightly or not at all, 2 = a little, 3 = moderately, 4 = quite a bit and 5 = extremely. The positive affect score is obtained by adding the scores on items 1, 3, 5, 9, 10, 12, 14, 16, 17 and 19. The range of the possible total score is 10-50 with higher scores indicating greater positive affect.

Negative affect will be measured with The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule-Short Form (PANAS-SF), a 20-item questionnaire with 10 items assessing positive affect and 10 items assessing negative affect. Participants will be asked to "indicate to what extent you feel this way right now, that is, at the present moment" on a five-point scale; 1 = very slightly or not at all, 2 = a little, 3 = moderately, 4 = quite a bit and 5 = extremely. The negative affect score is obtained by adding the scores on items 2, 4, 6, 7, 8, 11, 13, 15, 18 and 20. The range of the possible scores is 10-50 with higher scores indicating greater negative affect.

State anxiety will be measured with The State-Trait Anxiety Inventory-State Form (STAI-S), a 20-item questionnaire with equal numbers of anxiety-present (e.g., "I feel tense") and anxiety-absent descriptors (e.g., "I feel calm"). Participants will be asked to indicate " how you feel right now, that is, at this moment" on a four-point scale; 1= not at all, 2 = somewhat, 3 = moderately so, 4= very much so. The anxiety-absent items (1, 2, 5, 8, 10, 11, 15, 16, 19, 20) will be reverse scored, and then all 20-items will be summed to obtain the state anxiety score. The range of the possible scores is 20-80; higher scores indicate greater state anxiety.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to during body scan to 5-minutes post body scan
primary_outcome.description: Electrocardiogram (ECG) data will be used to calculate the root mean square of successive differences (RMSSD) between heartbeats and the high frequency heart rate variability (HF-HRV). ECG device with sampling rate >250 Hertz and connected to three gel electrodes attached to participants' forearms will be used to collect data with women seated quietly and breathing normally. ECG data will be visually inspected and manually corrected for artifacts, and then used to calculate the RMSSD of adjacent R-R intervals, and HF-HRV (0.15-0.40 Hz) by interpolating and filtering R-R intervals and applying a Fast Fourier Transformation. ECG data will be recorded for 5-minutes before the body scan to establish baseline vagal tone, during the 20-minutes body scan, and for 5-minutes post body scan.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 weeks post the in-person study visit.
primary_outcome.description: A subset of the sample (n=20) will complete a one-on-one telephone semi-structured interview to understand participant's perceived experience of the body scan exercise.

arm_group.description: Participants will listen to a 20-minute, audio-guided mindfulness-based body scan exercise.

intervention.description: The body scan is a core element of mindfulness-based stress reduction. Participants will listen to a 20-minute audio guide instructing them to focus on sensations in the body, place attention on one area of the body at a time, and progressively move attention throughout areas of the body.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- previously experienced a traumatic event as defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) more than 6 months prior
- self-identify as a woman and were assigned female sex at birth
- 18 years of age or older
- fluency in English
Exclusion Criteria:
- active suicidal thoughts with a plan
- unable to abstain from drugs or alcohol for at least 48 hours prior to study visit
- current or history of psychosis with auditory hallucination and/or visual hallucinations
- meditated or practiced yoga more than1 time(s) per month over past 6 months

eligibility.gender_description: Self-identify as a woman and were assigned female sex at birth
